data.title: Post-rock/post-metal/post-hardcore Era, get in here!
data.meta_description:
Alternative thread title: 4–6 white dudes attempt to reveal the face of god through textured guitar work


Whew, we have a lot of ground to cover here. I’m...
data.text:
Alternative thread title: 4–6 white dudes attempt to reveal the face of god through textured guitar work

Whew, we have a lot of ground to cover here. I'm very interested to see who else shares these particular musical tastes, and if anyone else is constantly on the hunt for their next musical hit. Post-whatever music is like a drug for me, and I'm always chasing those first-time-listen feels. No other genre gets me lifted like a good posty track. There's so much out there. This OP will just scratch the surface, and I'm hoping others will share and everyone will walk away with new shit to blast.

Since posts here are limited to two embeds, I'm going to link to a lot of stuff.

Post-rock

Everyone has heard the giants, so we won't touch much Explosions in the Sky, Mogwai, Godspeed You! Black Emperor, Sigur Rós, etc. This genre is absolutely fucking massive, but below are a few of my reliable groups that I will always be there on Day 1 for a new release, in no particular order:

If These Trees Could Talk:

Tides From Nebula

65daysofstatic

This Patch of Sky

pg.lost

*shels

There are also numerous bands that I have discovered recently, though their releases may not actually be recent. Below are a few that have really grabbed me, grabbed randomly from my playlists. Again, there is soooooooo much out there, this is just a drop in the bucket:

Goodbye, Titan

I Hear Sirens

Audrey Fall

Oh Hiroshima

powder! go away

Mooncake

sleepmakeswaves

Post-metal

If you prefer things a little heavier, I've got the genre for you. I personally classify a lot more bands with vocals as post-metal than I would with post-rock, though there are several instrumental-only bands below. This genre gets murky, with lots of crossover black metal and other sludgy subgenres:

Cult of Luna:

Rosetta

Celephaïs

Hourvari (sadly only lasted for one 2-song EP)

Celestial Wolves

Light Bearer

Kehlvin

Year of No Light

Sól (my buddy's band, so it gets a plug)

Post-Hardcore

These bands embody the spirit of the posty guitar, but mix it with the energy and vocal style of hardcore. Some of my favorite workout tracks can be found below:

Rinoa

envy

Taken

heaven in her arms

The Tidal Sleep

Crydebris

I could probably spend all week finding and adding artists to the lists above. To me, these genres represent the heights of rock and what it can evoke. I'll leave you with a link to a playlist my buddy maintains (same buddy as above) that updates monthly with new tracks from a variety of bands, though it does trend on the heavier side:

Spotify

Google Play Music

I haven't been able to keep up with any new music lately, especially within the genres aimed at for this thread but I still find time to listen to some of the stuff. I would say most of these bands I'll list could fall within any of those genres, some falling into math-rock. I'm just gonna link a random song from each one that I think is representative of their sound, not necessarily my favorites but whatever's available on YT.

And So I Watch You From Afar - Big Thinks do Remarkable - high energy, instrumental/math rock, some vocals

Mouse On The Keys - 最後の晩餐 - japanese instrumental jazz rock, no vocals

mudy on the 昨晩 - PERSON! PERSON!! - japanese instrumental/math rock, some vocals

Aurore Rien - Sunsets (I have seen too many without you) - slow/ambient post-rock, some vocals

Stage Kids - Face First - instrumental/math rock, no vocals

Have A Nice Life - Hunter - industrial/experimental/post-rock, vocals

The Antarcticans - Ghost of the Trees & the Erase of Man - sludgy/doom/hardcore instrumental rock, no vocals. i actually really miss these guys, very unique sound

The Redneck Manifesto - Another Day of Hunting - instrumental rock, no vocals

Japandroids - Sovereignty - post-hardcore, vocal heavy

I haven't been able to keep up with any new music lately, especially within the genres aimed at for this thread but I still find time to listen to some of the stuff. I would say most of these bands I'll list could fall within any of those genres, some falling into math-rock. I'm just gonna link a random song from each one that I think is representative of their sound, not necessarily my favorites but whatever's available on YT.

And So I Watch You From Afar - Big Thinks do Remarkable - high energy, instrumental/math rock, some vocals

Mouse On The Keys - 最後の晩餐 - japanese instrumental jazz rock, no vocals

mudy on the 昨晩 - PERSON! PERSON!! - japanese instrumental/math rock, some vocals

Aurore Rien - Sunsets (I have seen too many without you) - slow/ambient post-rock, some vocals

Stage Kids - Face First - instrumental/math rock, no vocals

Have A Nice Life - Hunter - industrial/experimental/post-rock, vocals

The Antarcticans - Ghost of the Trees & the Erase of Man - sludgy/doom/hardcore instrumental rock, no vocals. i actually really miss these guys, very unique sound

The Redneck Manifesto - Another Day of Hunting - instrumental rock, no vocals

Japandroids - Sovereignty - post-hardcore, vocal heavy

Thanks for these, I'm familiar with And So I Watch You From Afar and Japandroids, but not the rest. Looking forward to digging in.

This is another good pick, I need to spin this again.

World's End Girlfriend released an amazing album recently...

Not as good as Palmless Prayer/Mass Murder Refrain (one of my favourite albums ever) but still...excellent stuff.

Speaking of which, MONO have a new album out next year. Heard 3 or 4 tracks from it live last month, *so* good...

And I'll just name drop some random bands I've been listening to recently for people to check out...

Cataya

Degree of Arc

Heinali

Lang

Once Upon a Winter

Shadow Universe

Shekhina

Where the Good Way Lies

Wings of the Isang

Winterlight

Young Mountain

Yuki Murata

Oh and not recent but any excuse to post possibly my favourite song of all time...

Have a Nice Life - Earthmover

Carved out of stone

Earth, blood and bone

They knock the mountains down

The earth's grating sounds

They soothe the great machines

That yearn desperately

Just to lay them down

Within her gaping mouth

More than a symbol

More than I bargained for

More than a symbol

More than I bargained for

They wander ridges high

Between the earth and sky

Like spikes upon a crown

We wear upon our brow

And want is not a need

Reserved for human beings

Its fingers on your throat

Is pain that all things know

More than a symbol

More than I bargained for

More than a symbol

More than I bargained for

An army of the golems is stalking, now, the heart's lands

Eating all reality

Producing only dust and sand

Nothing hurts them

Nothing gets under their stone skin

And when their earthen mouths will open up

And just what words should come out but

"We wish we were dead"

Cool thread

Sumac is one of my current favorite post-metal bands, and one of the heaviest live acts I've seen in the last ten years – since Isis disbanded, basically. Aaron Turner is a god.

Some key faves:

Inter Arma are putting out a new record soon, but Paradise Gallows was one of my favorites from 2016. A number of media outlets put this at the top of their metal lists for the year and it was well deserved. They'd generally be considered post-metal but they really do it all.

Transfiguration

Examination of the... started out as a chaotic hardcore/screamo act, but by their last album (The Whitest of Elephants, 2003) they'd become a post-metal band through and through.

Kicking a Dead Horse Aside

Nadja is a band that doesn't need much on an introduction, but their discography is huge; oddly enough one of my favorite songs they've ever done is a cover of a Slayer classic.

Dead Skin Mask

Some other favorites from across the years not mentioned in the OP:

Altar of Plagues (post-black metal)

Planning for Burial

Zozobra

Ocean (not THE Ocean, but they're okay too)

A Storm of Light

Giant Squid

Nice OT, there's so many post-rock bands, I'll check some of these out.

Speaking of which, MONO have a new album out next year. Heard 3 or 4 tracks from it live last month, *so* good...

I saw them too a few weeks ago during their European Tour, it was an amazing experience to say the least.

They ended it with Ashes in the Snow, people were in trance.

Caspian and We Lost the Sea are also two amazing bands.

We Lost the Sea - A Gallant Gentleman : one of the best track from one of their best album.

"Departure Songs" is a journey from start to finish, and more people should experience it.

Caspian - Sycamore : A classic
